reviewText:
It's free-to-play and not necessarily pay-to-win on the original, better mobile version. You can also purchase units with medals in that version. No pressure, no harm done. You get medals over time (if you're willing to part with that) and so spending money is merely an express method to getting what you want faster.

It remains free-to-play in this version, but you cannot under any circumstances purchase units with medals. Instead, you have to fork out upwards of 30+ dollars (Canadian) for not individual units, but for entire packs of units. This monumentally insulting flaw paints this as an indisputable cash-grab, and nothing more. The original, mobile version was a decent way to kill time and didn't force you to spend money at all; this version is mostly unchanged but FORCES you to spend hard-earned money on units you might not even like, and in groups, too, rather than units that you actually want.

What if I don't want all of the Ptolemaic Army units but just want the Metal Rear? Well the joke is on me, then, because I'd have to fork out $16.99 regular price for that ONE pack (there are two for the Ptolemaic army, but that's just one group). The joke is not just on me, but on all of us.

So what of the way it plays? Well, unfortunately much of the interface remains unchanged. Sure, you can change the window resolution in the title screen, but that's the only thing that makes this resemble a PC title. On top of that, which buries the hatchet further, is the garbage control system. Somehow SNK Playmore missed the fact that you will be playing this version on the PC, which in most cases we can all assume will have a keyboard & mouse setup. You can use the mouse, but the controls are entirely designed with touch screens in mind. You know, the same screens adorning the mobile platform this game was originally made for. You have to click & hold your mouse and swipe to scroll horizontally (and as you go along, you'll do that a lot); you will have to do the same movement to scroll through the battlefield. All of this could have been changed with little work yet SNK didn't even bother.

So why should we bother, then? Why bother giving them dozens of dollars for apathy?

What is the excuse, that they were releasing it as a free-to-play so f*** it"? Why not just stick with the mobile platforms if you're going to be this unintuitive

reviewText:
What it is:
Directly ported, Free to Play, single lane tug of war game, using Metal Slug characters and stage art.

The good stuff:
Metal Slug fans will appreciate the old school art style, sound and music pieces
Competent tug of war mechanics, where most units have special attacks that you can (and you must) micromanage
The bad stuff:
Bad interface for mouse and keyboard control.  Having to swipe with the mouse to access all your units during missions is particularily awful.
Online 1v1 and 2v2 ranked and friendly game modes, which should be in the good stuff section, if it only worked.
Hilariously bad monetization.  Units are only unlocked by buying ridiculously overpriced DLC packs in the Steam store, on phone versions you could buy them with ingame 'currency'.  The PC version also has this currency, but it serves no real purpose here, it can be used to activate boosters instead.  It blows my mind.
Summed up:
Metal Slug Defense has some charm and I can see myself returning to this if only to get a bit further on the missions, but the bad interface and horrendous paid system is a huge deterrent against serious investment of both time, and money.  Just when you thought SNK couldn't possibly goof it up any further, we get this...

reviewText:
I have no nostalgia for the Metal Slug series, but can't imagine that could really save this game.
Gameplay consists of sending units from your base (you take a set of 8 different types) to destroy the base on the right, and that's it. Most units have a special attack that charges up over time and can be triggered.
This isn't a bad core concept, but it's also nothing special and it's easy to find free flash games that have a similar, if not better, execution.

On top of that there is an energy system, premium currency for booster items, regular currency for upgrading units and base attributes and DLC packages with characters that can't be acquired any other way.
With so many ways in which the game restricts you from having everything it should offer something amazing, and it simply does not.

There is little to no strategy involved in winning levels, requiring little more than grinding enough money from earlier levels to upgrade your units to be strong enough (or pay some premium currency for helpful/cheaty items).
The only thing that felt at least somewhat novel was the POW system (short for Prisoner Of War), in the levels you can free prisoners. Freeing all prisoners in an entire chapter gives you a passive boost to an aspect of gameplay separate of the base upgrades or unlocks new units. The problem is that even this system is weirdly designed and trying to get money out of you. Prisoners are 'hidden' across the levels in random locations that need to be hit with charged up special attacks. You can use a booster item (for every single level) to get at least one prisoner for completing the level, but even with that it could easily take 3-6 playthroughs of every level just to get all of them.

This game is free, so you should not expect much.
But I'd feel we should expect more than this.
Mobile games can be properly ported to Steam, but not like this.

Pros:  Fairly action-packed 2D tower defense game.  Many units have special moves you can click to use, adding a bit of strategy and timing to the gameplay.  A lot of different units available (though many locked behind a paywall).  Overall, a pretty fun game of it's type.

Cons:  While you can earn medals (real cash currency) in game, you can only buy temporary boosts and in-game currency with these medals. I've tried many times to find both 1v1 and 2v2, but never have found anyone to play with.

Essentially the game is fun in single-player mode.  But it falls flat after a while, when you realize the only reason you're grinding is to become stronger, but it's pointless when nobody else plays the game to compete with.  If you want more Steam achievements, that is really the only purpose to play, other than to pass a little time.  And games of this type are often free and a dime a dozen all over gaming sites like Kongregate.  It brings nothing new to the genre, but if you were to buy everything, you'd be spending close to $200 on a dead game.

reviewText:
Metal Slug Defense is a pretty good game if you like the genre.  If you've played games like Warfare 1917 then you might know what the gameplay is like.  It's a defense game where you need to combine offense and defense to push back the enemies and destroy the enemy base(or a boss in this game).  It's a type of gameplay that's easy to learn but can be difficult to master.  The game is great as a single player strategy game that you can play if you've got a little bit of time but I haven't played the vs mode yet.

This game doesn't play anything like the old Metal Slug games so if you're a fan of them then there's no guarantee that you'll like this.  The DLC is quite expensive and should be able to be earned in-game(my opinion) but you should be more than powerful enough to overpower the enemy if you grind a little.  There are reports of a bug that makes your SV-001 tank disappear if you remove it from your hand so I suggest checking the forums to see if it still exists before you think of removing it from your hand.

All in all it's still a fun game even with its flaws.  I suggest checking it out since it's F2P and you don't need to buy the DLC to enjoy it.  Probably would have been better as a $10 title that comes with all of the DLC.

reviewText:
For this review, I'll briefly focus on the good, meh and bad of the original mobile version before talking about the Steam version.


Good:

- Without too many issues, you can complete the game without spending a single dime if you're patient enough.
- A lot of stages, units etc.
- Good presentation.


Meh:

- Play this game in short bursts, because the gameplay can get repetitive and shallow. Though, there are rare occasions where there are stage hazards (invincible enemies underneath the playing field shooting upwards etc.) to mix things up.
- More grinding sessions than a dollar strip joint, but there is Autoplay for already completed levels and the occasional Raid option to cash in directly.


Bad:

- Medal prices are a TOTAL scam, given the huge amount of expensive units and items. Standard price is 30 Medals for a buck, while the sale price (100 for a buck) makes much more sense and should be standard instead. This is THE major flaw of the game.
- YMMV, but if you meet cheaters online, they WILL anger you for at least a minute.


===================


Now, moving on to the Steam version:

It has no improvements over the mobile version, it's a direct port. In fact, it's worse. It's in fact a bigger scam because you can't even buy units with Medals, you can only use real money. Not only that, you HAVE to buy them in packs, you can't pick the ones that you want.



Verdict: I don't know what's worse; this or King of Fighters 12.

reviewText:
Although everyone writes negative reviews for this game and I agree with them on some points. It's actually a fun game. It's definitely not like other Metal Slug games and it definitely has some overpriced DLC and broken matchmaking, which pairs you up against players that are way stronger than you are. You are also able to change your windows time to get more sortie points, which sort of goes around the sortie point limit you have.

About people saying the game is a bad mobile port. The only 2 things that annoyed me were the fact that the splashscreen said 'Tap the screen' and that you have to unnecessarily scroll through your units, which would have easily fit in the PC screen.

And about the people complaining about the graphics being bad when you play in full screen. It's sort of true, but people tend to forget that the graphics of this game are just like the old Metal Slugs and that those were not meant to be on huge monitors like me have these days and that the game can also be played in smaller windowed mode, which is just as fun.

reviewText: It's a Castle Defense styled Tower Defense, meaning your base is on one side of a flat, 2D path, the enemy's at the other end, and you send various units at each other with the ultimate goal of trying to destroy their base. For this style of game, Metal Slug Defense is okay. I've played better, I've played worse. The main problem here is how slapdash a PC port it is. Even in windowed mode the jaggies and low-res graphics will slice your eyeballs, and the game's menus and movement are still very much based around tapping and dragging. A mouse works, of course, but clumsily.\n\nI still recommend the game though, albeit barely, because it's free and you don't really need to buy anything to play it for a few hours. If you're wanting a Castle Defense styled game on your PC, well, I'd suggest you look up the excellent game CastleStorm instead. But if you don't want to pay any money, this one will do the job cheap and dirty.

The game itself is not that bad. It's pretty nice when you are on the toilet or visiting your wife's parents, but yeah, it's a mobile game. I don't think I will be playing it on the PC. But if you have never played it and wonder if it's any good, then just give it a go. It's free and you CAN actually play it without spending a dime.

The In-app purchases are not very well thought out in this port. I played this game on Android quite a bit and my favorite units are the natives. I would have probably gotten them in the Steam port too, if they weren't in a $30 bundle with some other stuff I don't need. I mean, the bundles ARE actually cheaper than playing on phone. You would easily spend more than the $30 buying them one by one.

But that's where this game goes wrong. The whole point of micro-transactions is to offer a lot of small and seemingly harmless purchases. Take Hearthstone for example. One pack of cards costs what? $1,5? That's nothing. However, the amount of packs I've bought is somewhere between 50 and 100 which totals over 75 bucks. Could have bought GTA V with that.

This turned out as more of a blog post than a review. Oh well, final verdict? I'm going to give it thumbs up, just because people keep downvoting it without even giving it a try first. Just give it a spin. It has a lot of Metal Slug charm and fairly low learning curve.

Wow... This is... Bad. Really bad.
I get it. It's a PC port of a mobile game. No wait. This is a straight *RIP*.
And it SHOULD R.I.♥♥♥♥. There's no option to turn off the music OR the sound, it's both or nothing, and I always hate that.
battles are hilariously small, short, and senseless. There's very little strategy to it.
The tutourial is built up like taking it slow and saving up money for stronger units is the better strategy, but no. You can just spam the 2 soldiers you get at the start and it'll be just as good, if not better. If anything, it'll be faster.
The screens are hilariously small which makes no sense. The second a unit goes off-screen, it's attacking the enemy base. Where's the tension from not knowing what your soldiers are doing?
Maybe it woulda been OK if your base LOOKED LIKE A BASE AND NOT LIKE A TUBE. And NOT 10 miles away from the EDGE OF THE SCREEN.
and of course, it's a mobile game, so MICROTRANSACTIONS GALORE. Bait everywhere, items you can use to overcome the challenge with your wallet and not your skill!
The units don't even look Metal Slug. When did you last see a banged-up driod with tank treads, clamper hands and tesla eyes... THAT LATER SHOOT LAZORS! Soldiers have grenades but NO GUNS? ARE YOU ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ME? Isn't the whole idea behind MS to GIVE TROOPS GUNS? Send bullets, grenades, explosions, nukes, lazors ALL OVER THE SCREEN?
The combat is unengaging, the little bit of music I heard was obnoxious and just unmatched, the interface is crap... Jesus. This game does NOTHING right.

As with all mobile->PC rips... AVOID LIKE FIRE

reviewText:
An enjoyable game when you got that extra time or when you start your morning pace.

1. All bases max out at Level 30, plus there are all 34 characters if I'm not mistaken and all Maxed Level 30.

2. The best unit I've used by far is the SV-Camel since it's cheap and fast to deploy to the front.

3. Max AP is 690 which took me about 11 hours and 30 minutes to fill up.

4. Tips: If you want to get extra resource drop quicker, you should deploy the samurai plane, it's the most effective resource collecting unit I've tried by far.

5. Always use the Wall barricade and max it up because it holds your front units from heavy attacks.

6. If you set for the daily missions, first aim for the ones with the highest AP, so that later you can get the POWs early and quick and you can easily focus on the easier missions later on. Always aim for the daily missions first because it will unlock more units which are stronger and better for late missions.

7. FYI Max number of medals gained from completing all missions would be 1005 in approx. since I never use up all of it and I never cheat in this game anyway.

8. If late missions too difficult you could try older easier missions that could give you more money for your HQ and unit upgrades. Check for the rewards gained. The best would be the daily missions since the 40AP missions give you 42000 plus 6000 if you finish with S.

9. ALWAYS upgrade your units especially since it will give you more MAX HP and improved firepower.

10. Never forget to use characters' abilities (flashing characters means they have special attacks available) since it gives you advantages when under siege. More characters deployed means more advantage over firepower. It's the SV-Camel I use that is most handy in most of the time. And make sure to have backup units like the Wall Barricade.

11. Use balanced units for missions that require them. In missions where zombie Fio spew hazardous long-range vommit, you need to unlock zombie Marco since he is capable of similar long-range attacks that could kill even Morden's Tank and the huge Robot thingy (screw the names I forget that often). You need backups though since zombie Marco is slow and has vulnerably poor HP. Some tanks would do, with the Kermit tank as the best tanker for the front.

12. When things went nuts, use Kermit Tank to sweep your foes away from the base.

14. I have lots of assignments with deadlines and what did I do? I wrote a thesis of gaming techniques instead dO.ob

15. I think I should get a 4-flat Steam Achievements Award on my finals result this semester.....zzzzZZZzzz
